Question Text: Compare and contrast the shapes of epidemic curves and their possible interpretations.

The shape of epidemic curves can provide important clues about when exposure to an illness-causing agent occurred and the possible source of infection, based on their interpretation.

If the shape of the curve suddenly increases to develop a steep up-slope and then descends just as rapidly, it suggests that exposure to the causal agent was probably over a brief period of time. There may be a common source of infection.

Question Text: Compare the surveillance goals for influenza caused by a new subtype with those for Influenza-like Illness (ILI).
answer:
The surveillance goals for influenza caused by a new subtype and Influenza-like Illness (ILI) have some similarities but also distinct differences.
For both, the primary goal is to monitor the seasonality of respiratory infections, signal the start and end of the influenza season, establish baseline levels of influenza and severe disease, describe circulating viruses, and identify locally circulating virus types and subtypes.

For ILI, there is also a focus on identifying and monitoring groups at high-risk of severe disease and complications from infection, assisting in understanding the relationship of virus strains to disease severity, and generating influenza data that can be used to estimate influenza burden.
